lead_paragraph: In the service of Bob Dole, an ominous baritone had just accused Bill Clinton of coddling illegal immigrants with criminal records. But the next sound heard on KFI-AM radio was an explosive guffaw. As John (or was it Ken?) of the ''John and Ken Show'' came back on the air, he found himself reading the next commercial, which had far less to do with the fate of the republic. Through his chortling, he protested, ''Don't schedule these after the political commercials, O.K.?'' before hawking a low-cost tire store: ''Next time somebody tells you their tire store is the last word in discounts -- punch him.''
abstract: As Bob Dole spends millions of dollars on television and radio ads in crucial state of California in final days of his campaign, he must compete not only with cacophony of product spots, but also with din of advertising for state's unusual array of ballot initiatives (M)

headline.main: Dole Ads Vie With Radio Cacophony
